bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Morris Fishbein, July 2, 1941

div1.p: Hench describes his yellow fever research and his speech at the unveiling of the Cornwell painting, suggesting that Fishbein might be interested in publishing the speech, perhaps including a reproduction of the painting, in the journal "Hygeia."

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Morris Fishbein, July 2, 1941
div1.opener:
July 2, 1941
Dr. Morris Fishbein
Editor, Journal of the A.M.A.
535 North Dearborn Street
Chicago, Illinois
My dear Doctor Fishbein:
div1.p:
For several years I have been making an investigation of certain unpub-
lished data regarding the work of Walter Reed and the conquest of yellow fever. To
obtain these data I have visited Havana twice, also a number of the survivors of the
experiments in various parts of this country. I have obtained much data from the
families of Drs. Reed, Agramonte and Lazear and from governmental sources in Washing-
ton and Cuba. Because of these studies I was called upon to advise Mr. Dean Cornwell,
the nationally known New York painter, regarding the details of the conquest as he
prepared his painting, “Conquerors of Yellow Fever”, the third in the series “Pioneers
in American Medicine” sponsored by Wyeth and Brothers.

I was also invited to give the dedicatory address of the unveiling of this
painting in Cleveland during the A.M.A.'s convention week as noted in the J.A.M.A.,
May 31. The affair was indeed a nice one; the invited group was small but very
select: The painting was unveiled by Walter Reed's daughter (Miss “Blossom” Reed)
in the presence of the mayor of Cleveland, Drs. Van Etten and Lahey (see enclosed
photos), Mr. John Kissinger, (one of the first two army privates to volunteer to
Reed for experimental inoculations in 1900) representatives from various medical
schools (especially Reed's alma mater, the University of Virginia) and art museums.
A few old friends of Walter Reed were also there from Washington. These included
Col. Siler and former Surgeon-General and Mrs. Ireland.

I mention these details to indicate that the affair was a very ethical
as well as a most pleasant one, although it was essentially part of an advertising
program of popular medical education sponsored by Wyeth and Brothers. Doubtless
you are familiar with Cornwell's previous paintings of Beaumont and of Osler.

My short talk was mainly a synopsis of the yellow fever conquest with
some brief passing references of new discoveries about this conquest. Dr. Walter
Simpson of Dayton, Ohio, has written me that he mentioned my talk to you and has
made the suggestion that it might be suitable for publication in Hygeia, since it
is written in nontechnical language. As yet I have made no plans to publish it but
would be glad indeed to have it considered for Hygeia. I believe that the Wyeth
folks would like to use it or parts of it as background information for a little
explanatory brochure which they may send out later when colored reproductions are
made available to physicians.

May I therefore submit for your consideration one of the mimeographed
copies I had made. If you consider it in general acceptable for Hygeia I would
like to make a few editorial changes here and there before submitting the final
copy. If the paper is considered by you, you may prefer to omit the first two
(introductory) pages and perhaps other allusions to the painting (page 10). In
a way I would regret this since the painting is such a splendid and interesting
one and one which I believe the readers of Hygeia would like to see. I believe
the paper would gain interest for laymen if it were illustrated with one of the
enclosed photographs, which show the painting in the background. Perhaps Drs.
Van Etten or Lahey would permit publication of this photo which appeared in cer-
tain newspapers, or perhaps it could be illustrated with a reproduction of the
painting, a reproduction either in black and white or even in color. I think
the Wyeth Company would be willing to lend color plates or even color inserts for a
such an article at no cost to you and expect nothing but some simple acknowledgement
of the source or ownership of the painting.

But whatever you decide to do I appreciate your consideration of my
paper.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
